awd_titl_txt: III: Small: Deep Learning for Gene Expression Pattern Image Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Biological image informatics is an emerging frontier in computational biology, as there is an urgent need to move beyond the manual inspection of images to computational analysis for accelerating scientific discoveries. Conventional methods commonly employ shallow machine learning models in which handcrafted image representations are computed and used in model construction. These approaches heavily rely on prior knowledge on the data and problems to compute appropriate image representations. Motivated by the recent success of deep learning methods in image-related domains, the objective of this project is to develop advanced deep learning models for automated representation learning from biological images. This project also facilitates the development of new courses and laboratory infrastructure for attracting graduate, undergraduate, and high school students, with an emphasis on those from underrepresented groups.

Specifically, this project focuses on the analysis of spatiotemporal gene expression pattern images in fruit fly and mouse. The key challenges lie in how to capture the intrinsic structures of biological problems and how to enable effective model training on small, manually labeled biological data sets. This project develops multi-instance, multi-task, hierarchical, and regularized deep learning models for incorporating the structures of biological problems. The multi-instance and multi-task models capture the complex relationships among inputs and outputs, respectively. The hierarchical and regularized models explicitly encode problem structures and make the results interpretable. In addition, transfer and unsupervised learning methods are developed to enable effective model training on small labeled data sets. These are achieved by integrating both labeled and unlabeled data sets across multiple domains. Altogether, this project is expected to result in a set of advanced deep learning methods for the efficient and effective analysis of biological images.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we develop an integrated research and education plan to study three key problems in biological data analysis: (1) How to perform automated prediction of expression patterns? (2) How to determine the developmental time of embryos? (3) How to transfer knowledge from related sources to boost the performance on new domains? Our proposed research investigations produce efficient computational methods for the annotation of existing and future biological data, resulting in significant advances in computational developmental biology and biological informatics. The developed computational methods unify the different protocols used by different studies and provide an integrative platform for comparative analysis. The transfer learning systems developed in this project is a key to expanding and reusing knowledge learned from existing data and applying them to new data by avoiding expensive data labeling processes. We also study related problems of biological data analysis, such as imbalanced data, out-of-distribution generalization. Overall, we study (1) how to learn faithful representations for biological data in the form of images and graphs using deep learning methods; (2) how to capture the structures in biological problems in the form of trees and graphs; (3) how to deal with complex but realistic learning situations, such as imbalanced data, out-of-distribution generalization; (4) how to learn effectively when labeled samples are not readily available. We developed effective and provably complete deep learning methods for learning from biological images and graphs. We developed multi-task learning methods for capturing biological structures as trees and graphs. We developed deep learning models, loss functions, and data sets for imbalanced data and out-of-distribution data. We developed few shot and self-supervised learning methods for model training with few or no labeled samples.

 


Last Modified: 08/02/2023
Modified by: Shuiwang Ji
